Tornado activity:

East Canton-area historical tornado activity is slightly below Ohio state average. It is 8% greater than the overall U.S. average.

On 5/31/1985, a category F5 (max. wind speeds 261-318 mph) tornado 29.5 miles away from the East Canton village center killed 18 people and injured 310 people and caused between $50,000,000 and $500,000,000 in damages.

On 10/12/1978, a category F3 (max. wind speeds 158-206 mph) tornado 19.2 miles away from the village center injured 4 people and caused between $500,000 and $5,000,000 in damages.

Earthquake activity:

East Canton-area historical earthquake activity is significantly above Ohio state average. It is 48% smaller than the overall U.S. average.

On 9/25/1998 at 19:52:52, a magnitude 5.2 (4.8 MB, 4.3 MS, 5.2 LG, 4.5 MW, Depth: 3.1 mi, Class: Moderate, Intensity: VI - VII) earthquake occurred 67.3 miles away from East Canton center

On 1/31/1986 at 16:46:43, a magnitude 5.0 (5.0 MB) earthquake occurred 56.8 miles away from the city center

On 8/23/2011 at 17:51:04, a magnitude 5.8 (5.8 MW, Depth: 3.7 mi) earthquake occurred 267.8 miles away from East Canton center

On 7/27/1980 at 18:52:21, a magnitude 5.2 (5.1 MB, 4.7 MS, 5.0 UK, 5.2 UK) earthquake occurred 228.0 miles away from the city center

On 12/31/2011 at 20:05:01, a magnitude 4.0 (4.0 ML, Depth: 3.1 mi, Class: Light, Intensity: IV - V) earthquake occurred 39.1 miles away from the city center

On 7/12/1986 at 08:19:37, a magnitude 4.5 (4.5 MB) earthquake occurred 162.7 miles away from the city center

Magnitude types: regional Lg-wave magnitude (LG), body-wave magnitude (MB), local magnitude (ML), surface-wave magnitude (MS), moment magnitude (MW)

2002 - 2018 National Fire Incident Reporting System (NFIRS) incidents

Based on the data from the years 2002 - 2018 the average number of fires per year is 36. The highest number of fires - 58 took place in 2010, and the least - 3 in 2002. The data has a growing trend.

When looking into fire subcategories, the most incidents belonged to: Structure Fires (50.7%), and Outside Fires (37.5%).
